description.narrative: Strengthening national systems and capacities to support the coordination and implementation of Cambodia’s climate change response, contributing to a greener, low carbon, climate-resilient, equitable, sustainable and knowledge-based society
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Cambodia

description.narrative: 1. National M&E Framework is approved and functional including gender disaggregated and poverty indicators 2. Number of ministries with institutional arrangement to manage their Climate Change Action Plan (CCAP) and contribute to Climate Change Technical Team (CCTT) activities 3. Number of ministries that demonstrate capacity to implement at least 50% actions in their CCAPs and report on CCAP progress in line with national standards (incl. gender analysis) 4. Legal mandates for the National Climate Change Committee (NCCC), Climate Change Technical Team (CCTT) and NCCC secretariat strengthened

comment.narrative: Baseline 2014 1. A draft M&E Framework is under discussion 2. Two line ministries have Climate Change (CC) working groups (MOWA and MRD) 3. Climate Change Action Plan (CAP) is being finalized 4. Institutional and legal review is ongoing
1. The M&E framework contributes to NSDP mid-term review 2. Five line ministries 3. No line ministries 4. New Royal Decree and Sub-Decree drafted

1. National CC M&E framework finalized and launched. 2. Five ministries (including MAFF, MoWA, MRD, MoH, MPWT) have established climate change working groups or teams, with different levels of engagement. 3. An initial status/update on implementation of CCAPs will be available in 2017. 4. Royal decree on the NCSD and sub-decree on its General Secretariat were approved in 2015 (achieved).
1. M&E Data collection and analysis in line with approved procedures. 2. Seven line ministries 3. Two line ministries 4. Ministerial Prakas adopted in line with royal decree and sub-decree.

1. Achieved. M&E Data collection and analysis in line with approved procedures for the national M&E framework. Updated institutional indicators (2016) are available and 2016 impact indicators are being compiled. 2. Achieved. Seven ministries (MEF, MAFF, MoWA, MRD, MoH, MPWT, MOEYS) have established climate change working groups or teams, with different levels of engagement. All key ministries and agencies have focal points (20). 3. Information not yet available. A status/update on implementation of CCAPs will be available Q1 2018. 4. Achieved. Royal decree on the NCSD and Sub-decree on its General Secretariat were approved in 2015. Prakas for each department of NCSD and for the CC-TWG have been approved by Chair of NCSD. Four meetings of CC-TWG were conducted in 2017, including two with development partners.
1. M&E Data collection and analysis in line with approved procedures 2. Nine line ministries 3. Four line ministries 4. Ministerial Prakas adopted in line with royal decree and sub-decree

The project uses multi-media approaches aiming to improve knowledge and efficacy of young people for negotiating with decision makers for better employment opportunities and giving them soft skills and confidence needed to identity potential jobs.

activity-description.narrative: Main project operation: production of TV episode and radio talk show, capacity building of National Employment Agency, overall project management and coordination.

activity-description.narrative: The project intends to build confidence and self efficacy of youth, particularly women, in Cambodia to enable them to access skills and employment.

description.narrative: Other General Services - support to civil society

1. No. of young people reached through the multimedia initiative for youth on youth employment. 2. No. of TV episodes produced and broadcasted including an interactive programme of radio and online components. 3. A qualitative impact assessment conducted to assess the impact of the multimedia initiative for youth. 4. No. of NEA staff members have developed skills and greater understanding of how to produce and use media to increase youth employment knowledge and skills. 5. No. of CBS staff members have developed script writing skills strengthening their capacity to conceive and deliver original drama content.
Phase II (2017-2018): 1. Evidence of Young People’s (disaggregated by Gender) improved access to information on job opportunities and formal and informal ways to find employment to improve the way they make a living 2. Evidence of Young People’s (disaggregated by gender) improved knowledge and skills around seeking employment/ an occupation that will meet their economic and safety needs. 3. Evidence of young people’s (disaggregated by Gender) increased confidence and knowledge of strategies to discuss and negotiate with parents and other community powerholders on choices about young people’s livelihoods. 4. No. of young people reached through the multi-media initiative for youth on youth employment 5. NEA communication strategy developed 6. Evidence of NEA staff’s improved capacity in implement and monitor the communication strategy

comment.narrative:
Phase I (2014-2016): Baseline 2013: 1. 500,000 people 2. 0 3. No assessment being conducted 4. 0 5. 0
Phase II (2017 - 2018): 1. Klahan9 audiences reported their knowledge being reinforced including be brave and persevere to overcome obstacles in life, migration issues, employment issues (consider working conditions, prepare for interviews), discrimination against women at work and in the community, and the importance of communication skills. 2. Klahan 9 audiences didn’t report of having improved knowledge and skills around seeking employment/an occupation but reported that after watching Klahan9, they felt motivated to take action to ru and expand their own business; felt encouraged to continue studying; thought deeply about the risks before migrating for employment and felt better prepared for job interviews 3. Klahan9 audiences acknowledged that Klahan9 TV is educational as well as entertaining. They felt motivated and inspired by the programme to take action on their existing plans, but it is not clear how this motivation translated into action, particularly in terms of having confidence to negotiate with elders about livelihood choices. 4. 1,753,985 5. No communication strategy 6. NEA has limited capacity to implement and monitor the communications strategy.
1. 1,763,984 2. 10 TV episodes, 58 radio shows 3. An audience impact assessment conducted 4. 17 staffs 5. 11 staffs
1.1,998,738 2. 10 TV episodes, 58 radio shows 3. An audience impact assessment conducted 4. 28 staffs 5. 6 staffs

1. N/A (to be informed by impact evaluation research in 2018) 2. N/A (to be informed by impact evaluation research in 2018) 3. N/A (to be informed by impact evaluation research in 2018) 4. 2,123,989 5. Communication strategy drafted 6. NEA staff’s improved capacity in implement and monitor the communications strategy

1. N/A (to be informed by impact evaluation research in 2018) 2. N/A (to be informed by impact evaluation research in 2018) 3. N/A (to be informed by impact evaluation research in 2018) 4. 2,408,803 5. Communication strategy of NEA is drafted and to be finalized in early 2018 6. On-track - NEA staff’s improved capacity as they could draft the communication strategy by themselves, while the implementation and monitoring of the communications strategy will take place in 2018

1. Local Government Associations created for district councils. 2. Systems and procedures developed for operation of Local Government Associations. 3. No. of inputs/proposals into NCDD sub-committee debates. 4. District council members of expanded League of District, Municipality, Khan, Commune and Sangkat Councils or a separate association 5. Number of training courses designed and delivered to councils by Associations of Sub-national Administration Councils. 7. Number of inputs/proposals into NCDD sub-committee debates. 8. comment.narrative: 1. District councils do not have a Local Government Association which represents them. 2. Insufficient systems and procedures for operation of Local Government Associations. 3. inputs/proposals into NCDD sub-committee debates have been addressed.

1. N/A 2. N/A 3. N/A 4. District council members of expanded League of District, Municipality, Khan, Commune and Sangkat Councils or a separate association 5.1. Core staff of Secretariat of Associations of Sub-national Administration Councils recruited and on board. 5.2. POMM implemented by the Secretariat of Associations and MOM implemented by Secretariat of Provincial Associations 6.1. Capacity development plan updated in line with international standards, approved and implemented. 6.2. Training program designed in line with international standards, including thematic training modules. 6.3. Training courses delivered to governing bodies and professional staff of the Associations of Sub-national Administration Councils and its 25 Provincial Associations. 6.4. Grant provided to 12 PALC. 6.5. South-South cooperation through study tour/s aimed at enhancing the institutional capacity of the Associations of Sub-national Councils are organised/facilitated. 6.6. Support NCDD to facilitate the capacity development of SNA staff on how to promote social accountability and work effectively with citizens, CBOs and NGOs in 12 target provinces. 7.1 Institutional Needs Assessment conducted and Capacity Development Plan formulated 7.2 Advocacy strategy developed and partially implemented. 7.3. Grant provided to 12 PALC. 7.4. National, Regional, Provincial and district forums organized to response to councillors and citizen needs. 8. Number of services designed and delivered to councils. 9.1. Core staff of Secretariat of Associations of Sub-national Administration Councils recruited and on board.

5.1. Five Core staff of Secretariat of Associations of Sub-national Administration Councils recruited and on board. 5.2. POMM is endorsed and under implementation but official signing is still pending, while MOM has not yet been officially approved but it has been applied at 12 target PAs for ACES grant management 6.1. Capacity development plan drafted 6.2. Training program designed covering six training modules. 6.3. ToT delivered to ASAC-S core staff and PAs secretaries at ASAC-S office 6.4. Grant provided to 12 PALC. 6.5. Study tour conducted to Philippine 6.6. Support NCDD to facilitate the capacity development of SNA staff on how to promote social accountability and work effectively with citizens, CBOs and NGOs in 12 target provinces. 7.1 Institutional Needs Assessment conducted 7.2 Advocacy strategy drafted 7.3. Grant provided to 12 PALC. 7.4. 12 commune forums, 85 district fora, 12 provincial fora; 1 regional forum; 20 trainings/workshops, 8. Number of services designed and delivered to councils. 8. 122 advisory service provided to communes

1. Internal and External Audits conducted to all sources of funds under Associations and Secretariat. 2. 19 Training courses delivered to governing bodies and professional staff of the Associations of Sub-National Administration Councils and its 25 Provincial Associations (3,4) 3. Capacity development plan finalized 4. Institutional Needs Assessment conducted 5. Gender advocacy plan finalized 5. Two gender ToT training course conducted to ASAC, PAs and CWCA 7. 106 National, Regional, Provincial, District and Commune forums organized 8. Associations Strategic Plan finalized

1. Partially achieved: Internal and External Audits only conducted to ACES project fund while Membership Fee has not been audited 2. 19 Training courses delivered to governing bodies and professional staff of the Associations of Sub-National Administration Councils and its 25 Provincial Associations (3,4) 3. Capacity development plan was finalized by the ASAC and further submission to MoI for endorsement to be a formal manual for training to local councilors across the country 4. Institutional Needs Assessment is conducted and management response is developed 5. Partially achieved - Gender advocacy plan is almost finalized and will be completed in early 2018 5. Two gender ToT training course is conducted to ASAC, PAs and CWCA 7. 106 National, Regional, Provincial, District and Commune forums organized 8. Associations Strategic Plan finalized and in the process to be endorsed by NACPA and NLC

title.narrative: Forest Carbon Partnership Facility REDD+ Readiness(FCPF)

description.narrative: Forest Carbon Partnership Facility REDD+ Readiness Project (FCPF)

title.narrative: FCPF Project GMR UNDP Cambodia 22 August 2016
Consultant for the Preparatory Work for the Development of National Protected Areas Strategic Management Plan
Consultant to develop Action Plan for National Protected Areas Strategic Management Plan
Consultant to undertake Mid-Term Review of Cambodia REDD+
Development of a REDD+ Safeguards Information System (SIS) and Summary of Information (SOI) for Cambodia
Enhancement of Engagement of Local Communities and Indigenous Peoples in the Cambodia REDD+ Programme
International Consultant for Development of Monitoring and Evaluation Framework
National Consultant for Development of Monitoring and Evaluation Framework

description.narrative: The project aims to develop and enhance the Cambodian government’s capacities for tackling deforestation and forest degradation as well as for measuring, reviewing and verifying (MRV) emission reductions.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Nationwide with some pilot activities in Koh Kong province, Sihanouk province, Pursat province and Kampong Chhnang province.

description.narrative: 1. National REDD+ Readiness Coordination Mechanism Institutionalized 2. National REDD+ Strategy is developed 3. Subnational framework for REDD+ implementation developed 4. Monitoring system designed for REDD+

comment.narrative: 1. REDD+ Taskforce established but not fully operationalized 2. The process to develop national REDD+ strategy is initiated 3. Existing REDD+ demonstration in two sites 4. National Forest Monitoring System partially completed, and Forest Reference Emission Level (FREL) does not exist

1. Effective operation of the REDD+ Taskforce 2. National REDD+ Strategy finalized 3. 5 sites established for REDD+ demonstration 4. UNFCCC technical assessment incorporated into the Forest Reference Level (FRL)

1. REDD+ Taskforce functions effectively. A National workshop and a closed working group meeting organized to validate and finalize national REDD+ Strategy for RGC endorsement. 13th, 15th, and 16th Consultation Group meetings conducted. PEB 10th meeting conducted.
2. National REDD+ Strategy completed and technically endorsed by National REDD+ Taskforce for RGC approval.
3. All selected five demonstration sites established. Measures to address key drivers continue to be tested and progress well in line with agreed action plans. Midterm assessment conducted in all 5 demonstration sites. Assessment report completed.
4. FRL endorsed and submitted to UNCCC. FRL Technical assessment to start in 2017

1. Effective operation of the REDD+ Taskforce/Secretariat and Consultation Group 2. National REDD+ Strategy (NRS) endorsed 3. REDD+ demonstration activities in five sites implemented and evaluated 4. UNFCCC technical assessment (TA) suggestions incorporated in a modified FRL re-submission

1. REDD+ Taskforce functions effectively. PEB 12th meeting conducted on 23rd August 2017. 8th Taskforce meeting took place on 20-21 July 2017. 19th Consultation Group meeting conducted on 25-26 September 2017
2. National REDD+ Strategy (NRS) is endorsed by MAFF and MOE and is being reviewed by the Council of Ministers. NPASMP is endorsed.
3. REDD+ subnational activities implementation in all the 5 pilot sites completed. Key highlight results including (1) Partnership Forest (PF) legalization over 5,414 ha and 15 years management plan completed, (2) 5 years management plan to protect and conserve 4,500 ha of mangrove forest and 3,433 ha of flooded forest prepared and under review by FiA, and (3) 5 years management plan and action plans for implementation of a management plan for PKNP completed and endorsed by MoE.
4. FRL has been modified and improved based on technical annex rapport from UNFCCC-Assessment Team (AT) and has been resubmitted to UNFCCC.

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
total number of national SS&TC partnerships
number of national SS&TC partnerships delivering measurable and sustainable development benefits for participants

The project seeks to increase the quality of Cambodia’s cassava production, to improve processing and transformation techniques, to raise the standards of Cambodia’s cassava exporters and their products to meet existing and new market requirements.

participating-org.narrative: Enhanced Integrated Framework for Trade related Technical Assistance to LDC's Trust Fund manager

description.narrative: capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Nationwide. It engages at improving policy and capacity of producer and expertor.

provider-org.narrative: Enhanced Integrated Framework for Trade related Technical Assistance to LDC's Trust Fund manager
Enhanced Integrated Framework for Trade related Technical Assistance to LDC's Trust Fund manager
Enhanced Integrated Framework for Trade related Technical Assistance to LDC's Trust Fund manager
Enhanced Integrated Framework for Trade related Technical Assistance to LDC's Trust Fund manager
Enhanced Integrated Framework for Trade related Technical Assistance to LDC's Trust Fund manager
Enhanced Integrated Framework for Trade related Technical Assistance to LDC's Trust Fund manager

description.narrative: 1. Availability of an updated cassava value chain study 2. No. of association(s) of cassava exporters, processors and producers formulated to engage in policy dialogue, to find markets and to disseminate agricultural techniques for their members 3. Availability of public information in Khmer language on cassava export procedure and market access plan/strategy 4. No. of orientation/training on export procedure to cassava exporters/processors 5. Availability of capacity development plan for cassava associations 6. No. of potential international market for Cambodia's cassava export established 7. No. of training, knowledge sharing events, and exchange visits (as part of the implementation of the associations' capacity development plan) 8. Availability of knowledge product/research related to agriculture/cassava sector i.e. the environmental impact of cassava industry, contract farming models, etc. 9. Availability of draft national cassava policy or strategy.

comment.narrative: Baseline 2013 1. The latest value Chain study was produced in 2007 by Trade Promotion Department, Ministry of Commerce 2. There is no cassava associations established in targeted areas 3. There is no public information available in Khmer language on export procedure and requirements 4. There is no cassava associations in the targeted areas, hence no capacity development plan. 5. There is no connection with potential market, under UNDP support. 7. Limited knowledge product/research related to agriculture/cassava sector and there is no environmental impact of cassava industry and cassava contract farming models available yet. 8. No national cassava policy or strategy in place.

1. Value chain study finalized. 2. 8 cassava associations established as a legal entity in accordance to Cambodian law. 4. First orientation on export procedure, standard requirement, and export rules provided to exporters and processor 5. Capacity development plan of cassava associations developed. 6. One cassava starch export market identified and connection established. 8. Study on environmental impact of cassava processing in Cambodia conducted. The result and its proposed mitigation plan disseminated to relevant stakeholders

1. Value chain study finalized. 2. 8 cassava associations established and registered with the Ministry of Commerce, in accordance to Cambodian law. 4. An orientation on export procedure, standard requirement, and export rules provided to exporters and processor 5. Capacity assessment for the cassava associations was conducted and the capacity development plan was produced. 6. No export market identified 8. Environmental Impact Assessment on cassava processing was drafted

1. Finalized value chain study’s recommendations implemented by key stakeholders including the Ministry of Commerce. 2. Cassava associations actively engage at policy level on cassava related topics. 3 Export Guidebook and Market Penetration Strategy developed 4. One orientation on export procedures. 6. Three blocks of potential export markets identified and at least one market linked. 7. At least one training, knowledge sharing event, and exchange visit (as part of the implementation of the associations' capacity development plan) 8. Study on contract farming produced 9. National cassava policy drafted

1. The updated value chain study’s recommendations e.g. transhipment issues, trade facilitation at cross-border checkpoints, and support on the cassava policy formulation were implemented and addressed by the Ministry of Commerce. 2. The cassava associations are recognized as one of the key stakeholders in the development of the National Cassava policy/strategy. What is more, based on the project’s experiences and good practices, a Cassava Association Development Strategy was developed and circulated by the Ministry of Commerce to other cassava associations in Cambodia and to Government’s ministries. 3 The Export Guidebook and Market Penetration Strategy for Cambodia Cassava were produced. 4. One orientation on export procedures organized. 6. Three blocks of potential export markets identified: 1. India and Bangladesh; 2. Indonesia and Malaysia; 3. United Kingdoms, and Germany). A potential market (India) was linked with the suppliers in Cambodia. 7. Cambodia’s cassava associations have been continuing to improve their technical skills and to strengthen their networks with other countries’ cassava associations: an exchange knowledge workshop with cassava associations in Thailand; three trainings on integration of SMEs in global value chain, on environmental impact of cassava farming and production, and SPS provided to members of the Cambodia’s associations were included in every cassava related technical trainings provided by the project e.g. market information, SPS, and access to cassava market etc. 8. Rapid assessment/study on contract farming modalities in Cambodia produced. Importantly, a private company committed to test the identified contract farming modality for organic cassava production in Preah Vihea province, as a result of an exchange knowledge study tour for cassava processors and farmers to learn from the practice of contract farming in Cambodia’s rice sector. 9. Technical draft of cassava policy is being produced.

description.narrative: The project supports the Royal Government of Cambodia (RGC) in establishing an effective early warning system (EWS) for the timely preparation for extreme events, as well as climate resilient development planning.

title.narrative: Consultant to refine strategic approach to implement the Early Warning System project
Re-Advertisement:Technical Consultant for School Safety Initiative in Cambodia

description.narrative: The project supports the Royal Government of Cambodia (RGC) in establishing an effective early warning system (EWS) for the timely preparation for extreme events, as well as climate resilient development planning.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Nationwide. While some stations will be installed in various disaster prone areas (to be determined), the project also engage in building the capacity of relevant national institutions to collect, analyze and disseminate the information.

description.narrative: 1. Number of national, sectoral and sub-national plans informed by accurate and up-to-date climate information 2. Effective and timely EW/climate information dissemination mechanism established and functioning 3. Number and type of targeted institutions/individuals with increased capacity to assimilate and forecast climate and environmental information 4. Number and type of training/learning tools on forecasting/modeling available for newly recruited staff or for continued learning of existing staff 5. % change in agriculture productivity in select communities (data disaggregated by gender) 6. Number (national coverage) of automatic weather and climate monitoring network in Cambodia 7. Number and type of targeted individuals with increased capacity for O&M for EWS related infrastructure 8. Financing plan developed and % of financing plan funded for hardware and software O&M

comment.narrative: 1. 0 2. Not effective (Early warning information is disseminated, but there is no clear mechanism (including the roles, responsibilities and accountability of responsible institutions). There is no Standard of Operations and Procedure in place.) 3. 9 forecasters at the Department of Meteorology (DOM) but they do not currently serve as formal trainers, nor do they provide tailored weather products. 4. Training is generally provided by outside parties and is short term in nature. There is no data available on number of existing training in Cambodia. 5. Early warnings provided are not tailored sufficiently to inform planning at agriculture households level 6. 12 fully functional hydrological stations, 0 fully functional meteorological stations and 7. Currently the quality and the coverage of the operations and maintenance (O&M) are limited. 8. O&M is funded by the MOWRAM budget, which is however insufficient. There is no long-term financing plan for O&M.

3. Key institutions identified for capacity development to assimilate and forecast climate and environmental information 4. National capacity gaps and needs assessed for the preparation and implementation of capacity development plan 6. Mapping of the existing weather stations produced and gaps identified for the project to install the equipment. 7. Target groups of individuals and institutions (at national and sub-national levels) identified for O&M training for EWS related infrastructure

3. Yes: target group from three institutions (MOWRAM, MAFF, and NCDM) was identified for the capacity development for assimilation and forecasting climate and environmental information. 4. Yes: Capacity gap and need in the area of forecasting/modeling identified and the expert to provide the training identified. 6. Mapping of the automatic station and the climate monitoring network in Cambodia produced and the areas that need support from the project identified and endorsed by MOWRAM, to be further consult with donor agencies to avoid duplication. 7. Target group from MOWRAM at national and subnational level identified for the capacity building on O&M for EWS related infrastructure.
6. Contracts for the procurement of weather stations (hydro/meteo and software) issued and 30 % of the equipment delivered to Cambodia.

6. Procurement of the meteorology equipment is completed (installation to take place in Q1 2018). Procurement of hydrology software and equipment is ongoing (expect to be finalized and installed in Q1 2018).
Note: in 2017, the project was redesigned to include a clear financial sustainability plan, to revise project’s governance structure and its implementation modality.

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

1. Availability of an information management system covering the three Rio conventions 2. Availability of a common clearing house mechanism for the three Rio conventions 3. Negotiation capacity of Cambodia at the COP meeting and in other regional and global forums (measured by no. of country position papers, policy papers and COPs reports)

comment.narrative: 1. Existing systems and data architectures are not communicating efficiently and do not provide good availability to environmental knowledge. 2. Limited mechanisms in place to access, share and exchange environ-mental information. 3. Limited COP negotiations skills and knowledge

1. Key information and data related to the three Rio Conventions collected and report of the inventory of existing information and information management system drafted. 2. Key materials from COPs collected and review of similar web-based clearing house mechanism from other countries initiated. 3. Workplan to support capacity development of the three Rio Conventions drafted and material prepared for COPs.

1. Key information and data related to the three Rio Conventions collected and report of the inventory of existing information and information management system drafted and shared for comments. 2. Key materials from COPs collected for the website to be developed in 2017. The review of similar web-based clearing house mechanism from other countries initiated and information was shared to focal points. This needs to be further modified. 3. The drafting of the workplan to support capacity development of the three Rio Conventions was initiated. The project also collected and analyzed materials to be used by the Ministry of Environment in its preparation for COPs.

1. Availability of an information management system covering the three Rio conventions 2. Availability of a common clearing house mechanism for the three Rio conventions 3. Capacity development strategy produced and at least three briefs produced for 3Rio focal points

1. The assessment of the current state of Clearing House Mechanism (CHM) and Information Management System (IMS) in Cambodia was initiated and the reports reviewed and endorsed by the Ministry. Based on these ground works, a solid Proof of Concept for a Knowledge Portal at the Department of Geoinformation System (DGIS) that would serve all initiatives (in line with the mandate and draft strategy of DGIS) is being discussed and the offer is expected early January 2018. 2. A first CHM SWOT report on the current clearing house mechanisms drafted and accepted by the Ministry. A beta-version for the CHM is being produced and stakeholder consultations among the data users initiated to gauge their expectations. 3. Capacity development reports produced by external consultant. An outline for the capacity development strategy was produced and will be gradually filled with more information on IMS, CHM, gender, economic valuation, PES, communication and leadership. A brief for the SBSTTA21 and the WG8j-10 meeting in December in Montreal and a brief on the UNFCCC COP23 were produced for the CBD focal persons. A concept note for the establishment of the LD Knowledge Hub under the LDN SPI was produced for the UNCCD focal point.

description.narrative: The project aims to reduce the vulnerability of Cambodian vulnerable communities and groups through investments in small-scale water management infrastructure, technical assistance to resilient agricultural practices, and capacity building support.

activity-description.narrative: The project focuses on Siem Reap and Kampong Thom provinces where farmers are vulnerable to climate change. The selection was based on the level of vulnerabilities and existing CC adaptation activities or lack thereof.

description.narrative: 1. Number of District and Commune Investment Programs that include specific budgets for adaptation actions. 2. Number of engineers and technicians (public sector, private sector and civil society) trained in delivery of climate resilient water infrastructure. 3. Number of Resilient infrastructure measures introduced to prevent economic loss and co-financed by Commune/Sangkat Fund. 4. % of targeted households that have adopted resilient livelihoods under existing and projected climate change. 5. Fiscal incentive structure that incorporates adaptation as climate change risk management (i.e Performance Measurement for PBCRG) successfully introduced.

N/A - project was still under inception period.

1. At least 5 CIP include specific budgets for adaptation activities 2. At least 10 engineers and technicians trained using hands-on, demonstration scheme approach. At least 20% female 3. At least 25 climate resilient infrastructure schemes have been successfully implemented 4. At least 20% of households participating in livelihoods trainings adopted at least one resilient livelihood technique (half of the uptake is by women) 5. Improved system initiated in target districts

1. 20 Commune Investment/Development Plans integrate findings from Vulnerability Reduction Assessment.
2. 50 government officials (2 women) received technical training on Climate Resilient Infrastructure Design and Construction.
3. Six priority projects including 3 irrigation canals, 2 dams with spill ways and 1 community pond in five communes have been selected and are at design stage.
4. None (activity has not started)
5. Improved system is not yet initiated in target districts.

1. At least 40 CIPs include specific budgets for adaptation activities. 10 district CC strategies updated and reflected in the DIPs.
2. At least 20 engineers and technicians trained using hands-on, demonstration scheme approach. At least 20% female.
3. At least 26 climate resilient infrastructure schemes have been successfully implemented.
4. 40 farmer livelihood improvement groups formed. At least 20% of households participating in livelihoods trainings adopted at least one resilient livelihood technique (half of the uptake is by women).
5. Improved PBCR incentive system implemented in 10 target districts.

description.narrative: 1. Number of subsidiary legislations (sub-decrees, royal decrees, amendments) related to support the Ministry of Environment (MoE) new structure and functions to strengthen environmental management 2. comment.narrative: 2015: 1. 1 (Drafted sub-decree on the Ministry of Environment (MoE) structure) 2. Limited MoE’s institutional capacity to address environmental issues, especially in light of the environmental sector reform (that includes the review of the roles and functions of key national agencies responsible for environmental protection such as the MoE, MAFF, and sub-national administration). 3. 1 (only the National Council for Sustainable Development (NCSD), changed from the National Climate Change Committee in 2015, has better capacity to address climate changes issues compared to other national agencies.) 4. NCSD has a limited capacity to formulate relevant policies/regulations and to monitor and evaluate the implementation of these instruments. 5. N/A (regulations related to environmental protection are sporadic and require an update and consolidation). 6. 0 (the Code was not drafted) 7. No integrated ecosystem mapping available.

1. One legislations (sub-decrees, royal decrees, amendments) related to support the Ministry of Environment (MoE) new structure and functions to strengthen environmental management. 2. At least one MoE’s general directorate has its structures and human resources reviewed and its capacity assessed 5. 0 (National Protected Areas Strategic Management Plan and its action plan, the Environmental Impact Assessment and the Environmental Code drafted). 6. Two national consultations of the draft environmental code. 7. Environmental related data collected and consolidated, in preparation of the development of an Integrated Ecosystem Mapping which will be operationalized in 2018

1. 1 (Government’s sub-degree no. 135 (05 July 2016) on the organization and operationalisation of the Ministry of Environment was issued in July 2016 which entails the new roles and responsibilities of the Ministry as well as its new structures.) 2. The institutional capacity assessment and development of MoE’s General Department of Administration for Nature Conservation and Protection (GDANCP) started. 5. 0 (National Protected Area Strategic Management Plan (NPASMP) drafted and its action plan initiated. The Environmental Code and Environmental Impact Assessment law drafted.) 6. Two national consultations on the draft environmental code and a third consultative workshop with relevant Government ministries with a specific focus on environmental education. 7. 200 data layers consolidated (most of which were collected from the non-governmental organization).

2. To some extent (Strategy for the Department of Geospatial Information Service of MoE (2018-2022) submitted to MoE; Institutional assessments of needs and gaps of the General Department of Administration for Nature Conservation and Protection (GDANCP) in terms of Human Resources, Budget, Communications completed; Review of Resource Mobilization Options for the Ministry of Environment (MoE), completed; Communications 5 Year Strategy and Action Plan for MOE developed; Human Resources 5 Year Strategy and Action Plan for MOE developed) and Strategic Framework and Action Plan for MOE and National Council for Sustainable Development (NCSD) developed 4: NCSD actively engages in the review of the draft Environmental Code and lobbies with key relevant ministries to secure their endorsement during the Council of Ministers’ working sessions; Communications 5 Year Strategy and Action Plan for NCSD developed; Human Resources 5 Year Strategy and Action Plan for NCSD developed. 5. 1 (The Kulen Mountain National Park Management Plan completed.; revised draft Environmental Code submitted to MOE core team after extensive inter-ministerial reviews.) 6. at least 4 7: Report on Decision Support System to Inform Conservation and Landscape Planning finalized and submitted to MoE.

2. Strategy for the MoE’s Department of Geospatial Information Service (2018-2022) submitted to and approved by MoE-DGIS; Institutional assessments of needs and gaps of the General Department of Administration for Nature Conservation and Protection (GDANCP) in terms of Human Resources, Budget, Communications completed and approved by MOE-GDANCP; Review of Resource Mobilization Options for the Ministry of Environment (MoE) completed and approved by MOE-GDANCP; Communications 5 Year Strategy and Action Plan for MOE initiated but not completed; Human Resources 5 Year Strategy and Action Plan for MOE initiated but not completed, and 1 (Strategic Framework and Action Plan for MOE and National Council for Sustainable Development (NCSD) initiated, but not completed.). 4. Yes: a core team of NCSD was established to review the draft Environmental Code and to lobby with key relevant ministries for the endorsement of the Code; Communications 5 Year Strategy and Action Plan for NCSD initiated, but not completed; Human Resources 5 Year Strategy and Action Plan for NCSD initiated, but not completed. 5. 1 (The Kulen Mountain National Park Management Plan approved) 6. 5 (Three national consultations in 2017 on the revised draft Environmental Code.) 7. Final Report on Decision Support System to Inform Conservation and Landscape Planning submitted to and approved by the MoE-DGIS.

description.narrative: This project builds upon the existing FCPF project and aims to further enhance the capacities of the government of Cambodia for tackling deforestation and forest degradation to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

title.narrative: Supporting Monitoring & Measuring, Reviewing and Verification (MRV) development for the REDD+ implementation

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of new partnership mechanisms with funding for sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national and/or sub-national level
Number of additional females benefitting from livelihoods strengthened through solutions for management of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste
Number of men above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Number of women above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
Total number of people above 15 years of age who acquired new jobs through a UNDP-supported project on NRM, ecosystems services, chemicals and waste
The government of Cambodia becomes ready for REDD+ implementation, by creating an enabling policy and legal framework and building capacities for implementing polices.

description.narrative: The United Nations Volunteers (UNV), the India, Brazil and South Africa (IBSA) Fund and the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sport (MOEYS) have partnered to pilot an innovative approach on youth skills development through volunteering.

title.narrative: United for Youth Employment in Cambodia

description.narrative: United Nations Joint Programme (UNJP) aims to facilitate Cambodian young people to labor force while reducing in equalities particularly for disadvantaged and vulnerable group-and ensure young women and men are better able to meet labor demand.
